sec.p: The family of two-dimensional (2D) metal thiophosphates, M2 P2S6 (MPS3) (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Cd), has been widely explored for numerous properties such as energy storage, chemical intercalation, and magnetic properties in low dimensions.1–11 The synthesis and crystal structures are extensively studied by Hahn, Klinger, and Rouxel where they found that the layers are formed by the edge-shared MS6 and P2S 6 polyhedral units and held together by van der Waals (vdW) forces. 12–14 For several years, this van der Waals gap in M 2P2S6 was utilized for intercalating various host ions to tune the properties of 2D materials targeting specific applications. 2–4,15,16 During this intercalation process in aqueous medium Clement discovered that hydrated inorganic and some small organometallic cations intercalate in the van der Waals gap where the charge of the guest is compensated by leaching out intralayer metal ions as in M1– xPS3G2x ,(H2O)y (G is a guest species of +1 charge). 17 This intercalation was unusual as it did not involve electron transfer as in a reductive insertion but occurred through cation migration from solid to the solvent. 18 Due to the incorporation of hydration shell around the intercalant there is a huge expansion of inter-layer spacings, and subsequent effect of that on properties became an interesting area of research. For example, partly proton exchanged phase of Li-intercalated CdPS3, Cd 0.85PS3Li0.15H0.15, displayed excellent proton ion-conduction. 19 The crystal structure of this hydrated intercalated phase, is still unsettled except in few cases where it showed transition from monoclinic to more symmetric hexagonal crystal system. 20 Recently, Feng et al. reported the co-intercalation of NH3 and alkali metals into FePS3 layers employing liquid ammonia method, where charge compensation is achieved through charge transfer from alkali metal to FePS3 unit in compositions, A(NH3)xFePS3 (A = Li, K). 21 Taking cue from these hydrated or solvated alkali-ion intercalated phases, a new family of materials can be envisioned from M 2P2S6 structure through replacement of part of the divalent transition metal with alkali metals giving rise to a composition, A 2xM 2-x P2S6 (A = alkali ions, M = divalent metals, x = between 0 – 1). The derived crystal structures will be similar to the ion exchange intercalated phases of M2P2S6 but differ in the occupancy of transition metal sites. For example, in Li2 MP2S6, alkali ions occupy the van der Waals gap and half of the transition metal sites, while the ion exchange compounds have equivalent number of vacancies in the transition metal sites to balance the charge of intercalated ions leading to metal deficient phases. Li2M P2S6 phases can also be thought of derived from Li4 P2S6 by partially replacing Li-ions by a divalent metal. This also brings opportunities to employ solid-state metathesis route in which P2 S6 building unit containing precursor, Li4P2S6, can be reacted with metal chlorides to rationally synthesize Li2M P2S6 in so-called building-block approach. 22 , 23 In this approach, we hypothesize that alkali metal containing molecular building unit ( P2S6 4– ) during reaction with metal halides will remain intact to produce desired product (Li4-2xMxP2 S6) rationally through the partial replacement of alkali ions by the metal of the metal halide precursor, eliminating the possibility of formation of multiple products.

If the metal of choice is a transition metal, then the resulting Li4-2x MxP2S6 (where M is a +2 metal ion) can be a potential candidate for cathode. On the other hand, if it is a redox inactive metal then they could be candidate for solid electrolytes as equivalent number of vacancies can be created in Li4P2S6 by the replacement of two monovalent Li+ for every divalent M2+. Takada et al first reported the synthesis of Li4-2xM xP2S6 (M = Mg and Fe) under anhydrous conditions in sealed quartz tube and determined its crystal structure in the trigonal system ( P
3
-
1m). 24 , 25 Accordingly, Li2MgP2S 6 displayed couple of orders of higher Li-ion conductivity compared to pure Li 4P2S6, whose room temperature conductivity is found to be 1.6 x 10–7 S/cm, 24 while on the other hand Li2FeP 2S6 is a 3V cathode. 25
The Lotsch group showed that partial substitution of M3+ in Li4P2S6 can also stabilize trigonal Li4-2xMgxP2S6 structure type as in the case of Li4–3
x
Sc
x
P2 S6 (x = 0.358). 26 More recently, the Rodriguez group further expanded the family of Li2MP2S6 structure type with new compositions of Fe and Co and reported their magnetic properties. 27 Interestingly, they claimed that in Li 1.56Co0.71P2S6, P2S6 is redox noninnocent in nature and carries a –3 charge instead of –4. Considering the vast structural and compositional flexibility, ability to accommodate various host ions in the interlayer gap and generation of exotic magnetic properties as exemplified by the vacancy-containing M1– x PS3G2x,(H2O)y systems with different transition metals, the Li4-2xMxP2S 6 family of compounds can be considered as an important structure type that is still at its infancy. Further works on this class of materials is much sought after to answer questions related to solvent intercalation, noninnocence nature of P2 S6 unit and structural uniformity across the 1st transition series to further broaden the scope of applications.

In this work, we are reporting both metathesis building-block approach and stoichiometric routes of synthesis of Li2MP2S 6 (M = V, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and Zn) and showcasing various intercalation properties by this family of non-vdW 2D compounds. Reversible intercalation of atmospheric water and intake of ammonia molecules from liquid and gaseous ammonia are demonstrated. The ionic conductivity of anhydrous and hydrated Li2.56 Zn0.72P2S6 shows approximately four and five orders of higher Li-ion conduction, respectively, over Li4P2S6. Magnetic properties of Li2MP2S6 (M = Mn and Ni) are studied for the first time. Finally, we also report the electrochemical activity of Li2FeP2S6 with liquid electrolyte in a Li-ion battery for the first time.

The compounds with nominal composition of Li2MP2 S6 (M = V (1), Mn (2), Fe (3), Co (4), Ni (5), and Zn (6)) were synthesized by two different routes: (i) from stoichiometric metathetic reaction of the preformed Li-containing P2S6 building block, Li4P2S6, with metal chloride (MCl2, where M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn; VCl3) and (ii) by taking stoichiometric ratios of binaries and metallic elements. For the metathesis reactions, first, Li4P2S6 was synthesized following a reported procedure 28 and reacted with M Clx (M = V3+, Fe2+, M n2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni 2+ and Zn2+; 99.99%, Alfa Aesar) in equimolar ratio at 1 mM scale. For the second method, the solid-state reactions were carried out with 1 mM of Li2S (99.98%, Sigma Aldrich), 1 mM of metallic M powder (99.9%, Sigma Aldrich), and 1 mM of P2S5 (Sigma Aldrich) in vacuum sealed quartz ampoules. The precursors were loaded in a carbon coated quartz ampoule inside argon filled glove box (O2 <0.5 ppm, H2O <0.5 ppm). The ampoules were taken out of the glove box with air-tight adaptors to avoid any exposure to the air and were flame-sealed under vacuum. The ampoule with an inner diameter of 10 mm, outer diameter of 12 mm had a length of ~130 mm after sealing. In case of metathesis reactions, the ampoules were heated at a ramp of 35 °C/h to 650 °C and held at that temperature for 24 hours followed by cooling it to room temperature at 35 °C/h rate. For the non-metathetic stochiometric reactions, the sealed ampoules were heated in a temperature-controlled furnace at a ramping rate of 40 °C/h to 700 °C and dwelled at that temperature for 15 hours before cooling it to room temperature at 40 °C/h. The cooled ampoules were taken inside the glove box and samples were recovered. Dark brown colored compounds for V(1), Fe(3), Co(4) and Ni(5) while slightly off white samples for Mn(2) and Zn(6) were recovered from the reacted ampoules. A digital picture of the powder samples obtained from non-metathetic stoichiometric reactions is given in Figure S1, similar colored samples were also obtained from metathesis reactions. When exposed to air, all samples quickly absorb moisture and exfoliate within a matter of few minutes. The V(1) and Zn(6) tend to hydrolyze if left for extended time. However, the samples do not seem to be particularly sensitive to oxygen. Hence, handling of samples requires great care to measure the property of anhydrous samples. Crystals were picked by visual inspection under optical polarizing microscope from compounds 1, 2, and 4 for single-crystal X-ray diffraction from non-metathetic reactions and all the samples were finely ground using agate mortar and pestle to collect the powder X-ray diffraction data. For the ammonia intercalation reaction, 200 mg of compounds of 1 (V), 2 (Mn), 3 (Fe), and 5 (Ni) were preheated at 200 °C for 4 hours under vacuum and liquid ammonia was condensed on the sample taken in a sublimator. The details of the ammonia intercalation reaction from liquid ammonia are given in the SI. The PXRD of the ammonia intercalated samples was collected in air-tight cell and the TG-DSC was performed by quickly transferring the sample in the DSC cup.

Synthesized compounds were analyzed on elemental content using the ICP method and investigated by spectroscopic (IR, UV-Vis spectroscopy as diffused reflectance) methods, X-ray analysis (both single crystal and powder diffraction, including variable temperature), thermal analysis, scanning electron microscopy, ionic conductivity, electrochemical, and magnetic measurements. Further experimental details are presented in the Supporting Information section of this paper.

The crystal structures of 1 (V), 2 (Mn), 4 (Co) and the hydrated phase of 2, (2-HY-I), were solved from single-crystal intensity data sets. Further details of data collections are given in the SI. Both 1 and 4 crystallized in P
3
-
1m space group as previously reported for this class of layered materials with honeycomb ordering in the layers. All the atoms in the crystal structures were located from the difference Fourier maps and the weighted R factor, wR2, converged to a low value with no further residual electron densities. In both compounds, we found a mixed occupancy of Li/M (M = V and Co) in M site (Wyckoff site, 2d). Disorder in the phosphorous site was observed only in compound 1, with a small percentage of P being present in the Li-layer. These results (P-disorder) are slightly different from those reported by Takada et al for Fe 25 but similar to those reported by Takada et al for Mg in Li4–2xMgxP2S6 and by Diethrich et al for Co (discussed later). 24 , 27 Based on the occupancy refinements of Li/M, we arrived at the final compositions of Li2.5V0.5P 2S6 (1) and Li2.5Co0.75P2 S6 (4), assigning oxidation state of V and Co as +3 and +2, respectively. Compound 2 crystallized in rhombohedral space group of R
3
-
in trigonal cell setting. Unlike other structures, we found Mn atoms were present in two distinct Oh sites. The mixed occupancy of Mn1/Li1 (65%/35%) can be refined in 3 a Wyckoff site, while in the 6c Wyckoff site, 50% of the site is occupied by Mn2/Li2 (17.5%/32.5%) and the remaining 50% by the P2-dimer. The hydrated phase of compound 2 (2-HY-I), on the other hand crystallized in C2/m space group, where Mn1/Li1 occupies 4h Wyckoff site with a minor component of P2-dimer while the Oh site (4i) is occupied by P2 dimer with minor percentage of Mn/Li. From the Fourier map, we could locate the oxygen atoms bonded to the interlayer Li-site. It should be noted here that the crystals of these compounds are very thin plates, and it is extremely difficult to find a single-crystal that does not have any stacking fault or twinning. The crystal structure solutions of 2 and 2-HY-I may have artifacts from their approximate treatments as single domain crystals (including high R1 and Rint values, large difference map peaks, and anomalous thermal displacement parameters). The differences in the percentages of disordered atoms in the Oh site is also a consequence of single-domain treatment. However, the agreement between measured powder diffraction and simulated patterns from single-crystal coordinates (discussed below) indicates that the unit cells and crystal systems are likely correct, and our crystal structure at least qualitatively distinguishes between full and partly occupied metal atom sites. The crystal structure data and the refinement parameters are provided in Table 1 (for compounds 1 and 4) and Table S1 (for 2 and 2-HY-I). The selected bond lengths are given in Tables 2 and 3. The atomic coordinates of 1, 2, 4, and 2-HY-I from single-crystal structure solutions are given in Table S2 and can also be obtained from CCDC by quoting the following numbers: 2331996 (1), 2331707(2), 2331997(4), and 2331708 (2-HY-I).

The laboratory powder data of samples obtained from the metathesis and stoichiometric elemental route matched well with the simulated pattern of Li 2MP2S6 25 (Figures 1a and 1b), except for the CoCl2 reaction in metathesis route. The reaction between Li4P2S6 + CoCl2 did not produce the intended product, Li2CoP2S6, instead produce some unknown phase (Figure S2 ).

However, we also noticed an extra line around Q = 0.7 Å –1 (d = 8.97 Å) appearing consistently in all the compounds which was not from the as-synthesized phase. The low Q-space peak (at 0.7 Å–1) has been attributed to the intercalation of water in the interlamellar space by part of the sample as confirmed by the thermodiffractogram, IR, and TGA studies (discussed later). The sensitivity of these class of alkali metal intercalated 2D materials to absorb the atmospheric moisture is not unusual as it has been observed previously in several cases. 29–32 In addition, we collected high-resolution synchrotron powder X-ray diffraction (S-PXRD) data from APS (Argonne National Laboratory) for 2(Mn), 5(Ni), and hydrated phase of 2 (2-HY-I) to refine the data using the single-crystals coordinates of 2 (Mn), Fe, 25 and 2-HY-I, respectively. The anhydrous phase of compounds, 2 (Mn) and 5 (Ni), were generated by heating the samples at 200 oC for 6 hours under vacuum and sealed in a quartz capillary for data collection. The Rietveld refinement using GSAS-II 33

The refined unit cell parameters and bond length distributions of each atom were similar to our single crystal structure solution. To clear the uncertainty in the Li concertation and verify the compositions of each compound, we performed ICP-OES analysis on manually separated milligram amount of plate-shaped crystals of each sample from the stoichiometric elemental reaction products. The results of Li/M ratios of each compound from the analysis are in good agreement with our expected values from single-crystal and the refined composition from S-PXRD (Table S4). However, they do deviate from the nominal composition except for 2 (Mn) and 3 (Fe). It is thus safe to assign the following compositions for the compounds, Li 4-2xMxP2S6, where x = 0.5 for V(1), 1 for Mn(2) and Fe(3), 0.75 for Co(4), 0.8 for Ni(5), and 0.72 for Zn(6).

The magnetic properties of Co and Fe with composition Li1.56Co 0.71P2S6 and Li2.26Fe0.94P 2S6, have been reported recently by Diethrich et. al. 27 Herein we report preliminary magnetic properties of 2 and 5, mainly as a characterization tool to confirm the oxidation state of Mn and Ni and to evaluate if there is any magnetic transition. The temperature dependent molar magnetic susceptibility (χM) and inverse molar susceptibility (1/χM) of compounds 2 and 5 are shown in the Figure 3a and 3b. With lowering temperature from 300 to 2K, the molar magnetic susceptibility increases asymptotically and reaches a maximum of 0.287 and 0.200 emu mol –1 for compounds 2 and 5, respectively, at 2 K. Further, no divergence is observed in the FC and ZFC susceptibility indicating no magnetic ordering and the compounds are paramagnetic in nature between 300 and 2K. The 1/χM vs. T shows a liner region between 300 to 25 K and at lower temperatures the curve deviates from the linearity. From the liner fit of the curve at higher temperatures with Curie-Weiss law 1/χM = C/(T – θP), Weiss (θP), and Curie constant (C) are obtained. From Curie constant, the paramagnetic moment is calculated and compared with the theoretical spin only moments of Mn2+ and Ni2+ ions. are very close to the theoretically calculated values of 5.91 and 2.82 BM, respectively, confirming the +2 oxidation state of these transition metals and also indirectly confirming the compositions. The small negative value of the Weiss constant θP, –15.64 and –0.335, for 2 and 5, respectively, indicate presence of someantiferromagnetic correlations in the paramagnetic region, which could not lead to any AF ordering above 2K. The isothermal magnetization (M) measured at 5 K for both samples show a sluggish increase in magnetization and did not show any significant hysteresis while reversing the field (Figure 3c). However, in case of 5, we did observe a very small hysteresis, with a negligible remanent magnetization of 0.003Nβ (within the measurement uncertainty) and coercive field of ~11.2 Oe (Figure S4). The S-shaped nature and weak hysteresis may indicate presence of ferro/ferrimagnetic interactions at low temperatures which could not lead to long-range ferromagnetic ordering till 2K. The maximum magnetization of 0.931 and 0.506 Nβ for 2 and 5, respectively, reached at 5T are only 18.6 and 25.3 % of theirtheoretical saturation moment (Ms = gSNβ) assuming complete attainment of parallel spins.

DRS measurements were performed on each sample to estimate the optical band gap of the compounds. The (αhν)2 vs hν (eV) plot shows a flat line with few small jumps in the lower energy scale corresponding to weak d-d transition followed by a steep rise due to the electronic transition from the valence band to conduction band (Figure S5). The band gap was determined by the extrapolation of base flat line and the steep rise of the curves. The band gap of the compounds ranges from 1.5 to 3.65 eV (Table S5), indicating wide range of band gaps particularly useful for optoelectronic applications. It is to be noted here that band gaps of Li-inserted samples are close to the band gap of corresponding M2P2S6 phases. 2, 34

Compounds Li4-3xVxP2S6 (x = 0.5) (1), Li4-2xCoxP2S6 (x = 0.75) (4), and Li4-2xNixP2 S6 (x = 0.8) (5) crystallize in P
3
-
1m space group isostructural to Li4-3xScx P2S6 26 or Li4-2x MxP2S6 (M = Mg, Fe and Co). 24 , 25 , 27 The asymmetric unit of the crystal structures of 1 and 4 and 5, consist of one transition metal (V or Co or Ni) mixed occupied with Li (Li1), one disordered phosphorous split between P1 (major component) and P1A (minor component) for 1 (no disorder in P for 4 and 5), one sulfur, and one lithium sites, respectively (Figure 4a and 4b). In both cases 2D layers are formed in the ab-plane by edge sharing between MS6 octahedra themselves or between MS6 octahedra and P2S6 polyhedra and stacked along the c-axis with Li ions filling the inter-layer van der Waals gap (Figure 4c). Both structures form an ordered honeycomb layers connecting the transition metal sites in the ab-plane (Figure 4d).

Such honeycomb layers are stacked exactly on top of each other along c-axis with partially occupied Li atoms sandwiched between two such anionic honeycomb layers. The P – P dimer resides exactly in the middle of hexagon with P – P bond perpendicularly disposed to the honeycomb layers. The crystal structures can also be described in terms of packing of anions. The S-atoms form a hexagonal close-packing arrangements and they are stacked in ABAB fashion along the c-axis. Such stacking creates 6 octahedral (Oh) holes and 12 tetrahedral (Td) holes if the formula is written as Lix(M2-xLix)P 2S6. Here all the Td holes are empty and only 2/3rd of the Oh holes are filled when x = 1. The manner in which the Oh holes are filled makes this compound different from M2P2S6 and the Mn2-x,PS3G2x(H2O)y. 1, 17 , 18
P2-dimer and mixed M/Li together fill 1/2 of the Oh holes between two hcp layers, which alternate with cation layers in which only 1/6th of the Oh holes are filled by Li. When M is a +3 cation then Li-occupancy in pure Li-layer (Oh layer) is only 1/12th as in the case of 1. Since we have disorder in the P site in 1, which means a minor component (4.4 %) of P – P dimer takes up Oh holes in the pure Li-layers and the same amount of P2 vacancy created in the (V 2-xLix)P2 layer. A similar P2 distribution has been reported in the case of Li4–2 xMg xP2S6 and Li1.56Co0.71P 2S6. 24 , 27 However, in contrast to Li 1.56Co0.71P2S6 reported by Diethrich et al, 27 our crystal structure solution of compound, Li4-2xCoxP2S6 (x = 0.75) (4) differ significantly. In our solution, we have modelled the 2c site as jointly occupied by Co and Li holding their sum of occupancy as 100% while Diethrich et al refined transition metal site with vacancies without introducing any Li in that site and to balance the charge they concluded that P2S6 unit carries –3 charge instead of –4. Therefore, P2S6 unit is redox non innocent. In our modelling, Li2.5Co0.75 P2S6 is charge balanced with Co in 2+ oxidation state and the charge of [P – P] dimer is nominally +8 (Figure 4c). We have relied more on ICP-OES measurements to correlate our Li/M ratio. Compound 2 on the other hand, crystallizes in R
3
-
space group and the asymmetric unit consists of two Mn sites jointly occupied with Li (Mn1/Li1 and Mn2/Li2), one phosphorus dimer site (P2), three sulfur, and one lithium site (Figure 5a). The Mn2/Li2 in this case shares the same octahedral site as P2 (Figure 5b), where the center of the P – P dimer resides in the Oh hole. Further, the structure forms similar 2D layers through edge sharing MnS6 and P2S 6 units and stacked along c-axis. The interlayer gaps thus created are occupied by the Li atoms (Figure 5c). Also, by connecting the Mn2/Li2 sites in the layers, one could form a honeycomb lattice and Mn1/Li1 site can be located at the center of each honeycomb formed (Figure 5d). As a consequence of these differences in the layer topology crystal structure of Mn(2) is slightly different and crystallizes with tripled c-axis. The hydrated compound of 2 crystallizes in C2/ m space group. The crystal system is isostructural to previously reported Li2NiP2S6 35 and NH3 intercalated Li(NH3)xFePS3. 21
The asymmetric unit consists of one Mn1/Li1 mixed occupancy site, two sulfur (one disordered), two phosphorous, one oxygen, and one pure lithium site (Figure 5e). The hydrated phase also has the disorder of Mn/Li/P atom in the Oh site in the layers with minor component of P2. The structure is similar to the anhydrous phase with 2D layers formed by edge sharing MnS6 and P2S6 units. However, we found that the Li atom in the interlayer is accompanied by oxygen atoms from the intercalated water resulting in elongated c-axis (Figure 5f). During such elongation due to water intercalation, the layers of the structure undergoes restacking along the ab-plane accompanied by increase in β (104.33) that results in the crystallization in monoclinic system.

In order to address the possible noninnocence nature of P2S6 unit, we also performed metathesis reactions between Li4P2 S6 and MCl2/M¢Cl3 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn; M¢ = V), which can be represented by the following equations: Li4P2S6 + MCl2 = Li 2MP2S6 + 2LiCl, or Li4P2S 6 + M¢Cl3 = LiM¢P2S6 + 3LiCl, where Mn+ ion replaces part of Li from the Li4P 2S6 and the formation enthalpy of the by-product, LiCl(s) (–409 KJmol–1) 36
drives the reaction towards completion as demonstrated in the synthesis of LiMnPS4. 22
In these metatheses reactions pure phase materials are expected to form simply by exchange of ions in a topotactic manner without involving any oxidation/reduction of precursors avoiding chances of impurity phase(s) formation as shown in Figure 6.

To our expectation the powder diffraction patterns of metathesis route samples exactly match except for CoCl2 reaction with the stoichiometrically synthesized products along with lines for LiCl and small hydration peak at lower Q space (0.7 Å–1) (Figure 1a). However, we could not get a good size crystal to determine the single-crystal X-ray structure and refine the ratio of M/Li site. The ICP-OES analysis could not be performed as complete removal of the by-product LiCl from the as-synthesized product was challenging. Moreover, just from single-crystal refinement from such thin plate without ICP-based analysis may not have been enough to accurately establish the Li/M ratio. The redox noninnocence of P2S6 4– will be dictated by electron acceptability of P2S 64– which depends on the electronic band structure of P2S64– in LixMP2 S6. Though the electronic band structure of M2P2 S6 is still unsettled, but previous reliable calculations from tight-binding approach indicate that sP-P* and sp-s* orbitals in P2S64– lie in too high in energy to act as a good acceptor level, which makes P2S6 4– redox inactive. 37 , 38 However, accurate electronic band structure calculations of nominal Li2MP2 S6 would be required to verify the reducibility of P2S 64– unit. In addition to that, our metathesis reaction, CoCl2 + Li4P2S6, also did not produce LixCoP2S6, which may indicate some redox or hitherto unknown reaction path. Therefore, at this point we do not have enough evidence to conclude in favor or against non-innocence nature of P2S64-.

As mentioned earlier, we have consistently observed a low Q-space peak (Q = 0.7 Å–1) along with the expected lines for pure phase compound in all our PXRD patterns (Figure 1). We discarded the idea of an impurity phase as we are not expecting same impurity from the metathesis reactions as well. The only other possibility for the appearance of Q = 0.7 Å–1 line might be due to interlayer expansion caused by intercalation of water molecule in a small fraction of the samples. Though samples are always handled inside glovebox and taken out in air-tight cell, it turns out that sample can intercalate moisture if the glovebox moisture reading rises above 2-3 ppm. A similar situation was encountered recently with Na-containing 2D gallium chalcogenides. 29 , 32 Therefore, we intentionally placed our samples in air for three days. The powder patterns completely transformed into fully hydrated phase with a high intense line at Q = 0.7 Å–1 after one day and into another hydrated phase with further shift of the low angle line at Q = 0.53 Å –1 (d = 11.75 Å) after three days. The one-day and three-day air exposed samples are thus termed as hydrated phase–I (HY-I) and -II (HY-II), respectively (Figure 7). This is evident in all the samples, 1 – 6, indicating propensity for water intercalation with concomitant inter-layer expansion by these com pounds.

Fortunately, we are able to collect single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for the hydrated phase of compound 2 (Mn). The Li atom in the interlayer is bonded with two oxygen atoms of water in the Li-plane and resulted in the expansion of lattice constant along c-axis (Figure 5f). The Rietveld refinement of S-PXRD of hydrated phase of 2, presumably 2-HY-I, using the single-crystal coordinates converged reasonably well with lower R W , however, huge intensity mismatch is still observed due to the preferred orientations (Figure S3). Note that an ordered structure coordinates were used for the refinement ignoring the minor disordered component. The final refinement parameters are given in Table S1 along with the lattice constants which are close to our single-crystal structure solution. Since the PXRD of this hydrated phase display first line at Q = 0.7 Å–1 ( d = 8.97 Å), we designate this as hydrated phase-I and it has three molecules of water as water of hydration, Li2MnP2S 6×3H2O. To verify the reversibility of hydration-dehydration of these compounds, samples were transferred to an in-situ heating chamber for the thermodiffractogram studies. Even with minimal exposure of the samples to air while transferring into the Ar-purged heating chamber, the materials partly transform into hydrated phase-I by spontaneous intercalation of water. This is evident by the room temperature PXRD before the start of heat treatment of the sample for thermodiffractogram as shown in Figure 8 for 2-HY-I and Figures S6 – S10 (for rest of the samples). The results of thermodiffractogram indicate that ~100 °C, the hydrated structure transforms into anhydrous phase. Interestingly the PXRD line intensities of the compounds get progressively better due to annealing at higher temperatures. Except for lines shifting towards slightly lower angles due to volume expansion (due to increase in thermal vibration) no further changes are observed indicating that the compounds are crystalline and stable until 600 °C. Upon returning to room temperature with Ar gas flow, the samples remain in anhydrous phase. The moment the samples are exposed to air, they transform into hydrated phase, except in case of 6 (Zn), where an irreversible decomposition (Li2.56Zn0.72P2 S6 = ZnS + uncharacterized phases) occurs at 600 °C and does not return to Li2ZnP2S6 phase at room temperature (Figure S9). The structural transformation/decomposition for 6 is further confirmed by simultaneous TGA-DSC experiments (discussed below). The difference in PXRD pattern of air exposed sample before and after heat treatment during the thermodiffractogram experiment is due to two reasons. The first one is due to the difference in data collection procedure and exposure time of sample to the air. Initially, the sample was briefly exposed to air and loaded into the Ar-flowing in-situ heating chamber with beryllium window for the first data collection (mentioned as 25 °C in air). After the thermodiffractogram, the sample was again re-exposed to air for a longer time before the data collection and without the use of beryllium window heating chamber, it resulted in much higher intensity of peak with emergence of new peaks that were not well resolved in the initial patterns. Secondly, annealing at high temperature also removes some of the stacking faults and intercalation of water in those samples may yield some well-resolved lines and even new lines. The PXRD (Figure 7b) of the three days air exposed samples display maximum extent of water intercalation by these compounds.

The structures are completely transformed into fully hydrated phases, so called HY-II, after three days exposure in air. For 1 – 5, the transformation is significant as evident by the appearance of a high intensity line at much lower Q-space (Q = 0.53 Å–1 , d = 11.75 Å) leading to further expansion of interlayer space in HY–II. In the case of 6, there is no sign of hydrated phase–II, rather than developing a new line at lower Q–space, the line at Q = 0.7 Å–1 moves to 0.81 Å–1 and forms stable hydrated phase–I¢. The nature (crystal structure) of this hydrated phase-I’ is still unknown to us. Note that this phase starts to appear in one-day exposed sample with a small line at Q = 0.81 Å–1. This clearly shows that except for Zn (6), where we observed one hydrated phase (monolayer), the water intercalation into the inter-layer space of the structure can happen in a two-steps manner, forming a monolayer (hydrated phase–I) followed bybilayer formation of water (hydrated phase–II) as supported by two endothermic peaks in DSC curves (discussed below) and akin to those vacancy bearing M1– xPS3G2x(H2O)y phases. 17 , 18 Since the (00l) lines are the only most intense lines in hydrated phases, we could calculate expansion along c-axis and the interlayer d-spacing to correlate with the amount of water intercalation. The interlayer d-spacing along c-axis for anhydrous Li2MP2S6 is ~6.61 Å. The hydrated phase-I with first line at Q = 0.7 Å–1 has a d-spacing of 8.97 Å with a difference of Δd = 2.36 Å, which approximately equals to the van der Waals diameter of a water molecule (2.7 Å). Thus, this hydrated phase-I can be assigned with monolayer of water molecules intercalation in the Li-layer. In the case of hydrated phase-II, which is a fully hydrated phase with Q = 0.53 Å–1 and a d-spacing of 11.75 Å results into Δd = 5.14 Å. In the absence of single-crystal structure solution of the fully hydrated (HY-II) phase, we hypothesize that this corresponds to a bilayer of water as shown schematically in Figure 9.

Although the exposure time is same for all the compounds, the degree of hydration varies from sample to sample. These water intercalation reactions are classic examples of post-synthetic modification of 2D-layered chalcogenides with single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation recently reviewed by Berseneva and zur Loye. 39

To get further insights on the amount of water intake by each sample at hydrated phase – I and -II and determine the thermal stability, we performed simultaneous TGA-DSC experiments. Since the hydration enthalpy of Li+ (ΔH = –519 KJ/mol) is higher than any other alkali metals, 40 the samples intercalated significant amount of water in comparison with previously reported Na+ based sulfides and selenides. 29 , 30 , 32 The TGA-DSC plots of HY – I (Figure 10) and – II (Figure S11) show a weight loss ∼15% (~3 H2O) and ∼25% (~6 H2O), respectively, from room temperature to 200 °C. In the hydrated phase – II, ~6 molecules of water per formula unit corresponds to each interlayer Li satisfying 6-coordination with water as in the chemical formula, Li(H2O)6(Li/M)P2S6 (Figure S11).

From the d-spacing calculation it appears to form a bilayer of water fully satisfying the Li-coordination with water. In contrast HY-I has water bonded to Li in the basal plane, while Li is still interacting (weakly) with S-donor in axial sites in trigonal prismatic coordination with d(Li – S)av of 3.52(9) Å as in the case of 2(Mn)-HY-I. The DSC curves for HY-II phases (Figure S11) also show two endothermic peaks below 200 °C, indicating that the water is removed from the structure in two steps. After the initial weight loss due to water, the compounds remain stable until 600 °C followed by a significant weight loss due to reaction with impurity oxygen in UHP argon with sulfide surface (Figure S11). The hydrated phase – II of 4 (Co) and 6 (Zn) are quite different from the others showing ∼37.5 % and 35% weight loss, respectively, corresponding to ~10 molecules of water in the structure (Figure S11c and S11e). It is highly likely that there be more hydrated phases besides HY-I and -II.

Also, 4 remains stable until 600 °C as the other compounds in the series, while 6 decomposes peritectically ∼425 °C. This transformation was clearly visualized earlier while performing thermal diffractogram of compound 6. Also note that even for Zn-HY-1, TGA shows higher water loss (~20%), which is due to emergence of another phase that we have attributed as hydrated phase-I’ with no structural information.

We also performed FTIR on all the air exposed samples ( Figure 11 ), the bands present around 550 and 605 cm–1 in all samples corresponds to the asymmetric stretching 41 , 42 of PS3 indicating the presence of P2S6 building unit in the hydrated phases. All the compounds exhibit absorption bandscorresponding to symmetric (ν1) and antisymmetric (ν3) - O – H stretching centered at 3418.5 cm–1 and H – O – H bending modes at 1608 cm–1. 29 , 42 Additionally, a weak band around 2100 cm–1 is also observed in all samples due to the combination of bending and liberational modes. These results further confirm the presence of intercalated water inthe structure.

The SEM images of a partially hydrated samples before and after thermodiffractogram studies were acquired as a typical example to examine any occurrence of morphological changes in the structure (Figure S12). The water intercalated samples of 6 shows cracks in the layers along with slight expansion due to the swelling. The images of samples taken after thermodiffractogram study show retention of cracks between the layers in the structure. The formation of two different phases in 6 is evident from the visual inspection of the color contrast in the image. This also supports the structural decomposition of Li2.56Zn 0.72P2S6 beyond 425 °C. It is to be noted that this decomposition of 6 at 425 °C is only triggered when we heat the hydrated phase.

As the structure exhibited good reversibility on water intercalation, we wanted to evaluate whether insertion of NH3 is possible in a similar manner. Ammonia intercalation into the interlayer space can regulate the physical properties of the materials as the binding of Li+ with nitrogen donor is stronger than oxygen donor. To study ammonia intercalation first we wanted to intercalate ammonia to fully dehydrated selected samples from moisture free purified liquid ammonia and generate authentic IR spectra with signature absorption bands for ammonia. The details of NH3 intercalation experiment are given in the SI. The PXRD of ammonia intercalated samples of 1 – 3, and 5 show a similar pattern as the hydrated phase-I with the high intense peak at Q-spacing of 0.68 Å –1, (d = 9.23 Å) for all the compounds, which is presumably a monolayer of ammonia intercalation (Figure 12a). To further confirm the presence of ammonia and rule out the ambiguity with water intercalation, FTIR spectra were collected for all four samples (Figure 12b). The peak at 3350 cm–1 in all the samples is attributed to the symmetric stretching of intercalated NH3. The NH3 bending vibration peaks can be clearly seen at 1554 (asymmetric) and 1110 cm–1 (symmetric/umbrella modes) further confirming the intercalation of ammonia into the structure with interlayer expansion. 43 However, the degree of NH3 intercalation slightly varies from sample to sample. TG-DSC has been used to quantify the amount of intercalated ammonia, which suggest varying degree of intercalated ammonia, Li 2MP2S6×xNH3, x = 2.2, 2.4, 3.1, and 2.2 for 1, 2, 3, and 5, respectively (Figure S13 a – d). It is also instructive to compare the ammoniated Li intercalation in FePS3 leading to the composition Li(NH3)xFePS3 reported by Feng et al 21 to our ammoniated phase, Li2 FeP2S6×~3NH3. To a first glance at the PXRDs, one can see similarity. The first line exactly coincides, however, there are subtle differences in the high angle lines both in terms of position and intensity (Figure S14). Another notable difference is that in reported Li(NH3)xFePS3, Li is inserted reductively lowering the oxidation state of iron from Fe2+, while in the present case it is just solvation of Li+ in the interlamellar space of pre-lithiated Li2FeP2S6 with no redox taking place. Due to its sustainable hydrogen density, NH3 is regarded as a potential medium for hydrogen storage. 44 As a result, the reversible solid-state storage of NH3 molecules while avoiding material corrosion is emerging as a promising field. 45 In this regard, we wanted to evaluate the selectivity of NH3 molecule intercalation over H2O in the interlayers, since ammonia is always contaminated with moisture. We exposed compounds 2 (Mn), 3 (Fe), and 5 (Ni) in air for one day to achieve the first hydrated phase (HY – I). These samples were then subjected to NH3 gas purging for 6 hours and then the samples were recovered inside the glove box. FTIR studies on these samples (Figure 12c) show the same characteristic peaks as observed when we intercalated NH3 molecule from liquid ammonia. These results further prove that these samples have higher selectivity for NH3 molecule intercalation over H2O. One of the likely reasons for this observation may stem from that the fact that ammoniation enthalpy is slightly higher than hydration for Li+. 40 , 46 , 47 The difference in IR spectra of H 2O and NH3 intercalated samples are shown in Figure S15 as a typical example for M = Mn phase. Hence, the Li2MP2S6 family of compounds with high selectivity and propensity for reversible intercalation of NH3 molecules can potentially be a suitable class of materials for ammonia storage.

As mentioned earlier 2D vdW thiophosphates, MPS3/M2P2 S6, are well known for their intercalation chemistry of several guest ions and molecules such as Li, Na, K, NH3, and pyridine and many others. Such variety of intercalation is possible due to the flexible van der Waals gap between the layers to host the hydrated guest species charge compensated by the removal of intralayer metal ions, M1–xPS 3G2x,(H2O)y or through reductive process. Through such intercalations, this class of materials exhibited wide range of applications in optical, electrical, magnetic, super ionic conductors and energy storage fields. This wealth of literatures gives us a plenty of opportunities to explore the intercalation chemistry of these pre-lithiated thiophosphate structures with different transition metal ions, Li2x(M 2-xLix) P2S6. Additionally, these group of compounds also provides opportunity for oxidative de-intercalation, which is not possible in classic vdW M2P2 S6. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first-time report of water and ammonia intercalation in Li2MP2 S6 structure type.

Since we are replacing half of the lithium from Li4P2S 6 by a +2 ion, it is expected that more vacancies will be created, and Li-ionic conductivity will increase. We, therefore, wanted to test our hypothesis by measuring the ionic conductivity of the non-redox active metal containing compound, Li2.56Zn0.72P2S6 (6). Ionic conductivity of the anhydrous and hydrated phase ( HY-I) of 6 was measured using AC impedance spectroscopy. The Nyquist plot of the impedance spectra consists of a semi-circle at high frequency region due to bulk resistance followed by a slope at lower frequency attributed to the charge accumulation at the blocking electrode (Figure 13a). The room temperature ionic conductivity is calculated from the bulk resistance of the material in the Nyquist plot by fitting the spectra using equivalent circuit given in SI (Figure S16). As the ionic conductivity of 6 follows Arrhenius behavior with rise in temperature, the activation energy (Ea) is calculated using the equation, σT = σ0 exp(-Ea/ KBT) where σT is the ionic conductivity, σ0 is a pre-exponential factor, T is the absolute temperature, and kB is the Boltzmann constant. Room temperature ionic conductivity of anhydrous 6 is 2.69 × 10–3 mS/cm with an activation energy of 0.48 eV. The ionic conductivity of anhydrous 6 is four orders of magnitude higher than crystalline Li4P2S 6 (1.6 × 10–7 mS/cm) at room temperature. 48 Such increase in ionic conductivity is due to the substitution of 2Li+ by one Zn2+ in Li4 P2S6 creating more vacancyor more room for facile 2D Li+ ion conduction path. The hydrated phase ( HY-I) of 6 showed a much higher ionic conductivity of 1.85 × 10–2 mS/cm which is approximately seven-fold higher than the anhydrous phase (Figure 13b) with an activation energy of 0.45 eV. The improved ionic conductivity can be explained as an effect of expanded interlayer spacing of the compound through water intercalation that facilitates better mobility of Li+ ions. Similar cases of hydration mediated ionic conductivity improvements have been reported recently in Na-based chalco-gallates. 29 , 32 It is to be noted here that while we were preparing this manuscript, we noticed another article reporting ionic conductivity of Li4-2xZnxP2S6, where they also obtained similar values of ionic conductivity. 49

Li-ion coin cells were made with Li2FeP2S6 ( 3) as cathode and Li metal as anode to evaluate the reversibility of electrochemical Li+ (de)intercalation from the structure. Several MPS 3 thiophosphate-based materials have been explored as an anode delivering high capacities through a conversion mechanism and some are also tested as primary Li-ion cells. 50 , 51 However, the pre-lithiated Li2 MP2S6 structure-type has not been extensively explored as an intercalation cathode for Li-ion batteries. Such compositions provide the opportunity to access the M2+/3+ redox couple at a higher voltage through the deintercalation of Li+ from the structure. Also, in the recent times achieving high energy density cathodes through cation and sulfide anion redox gives an opportunity for different class of thiophosphate to be explored as a feasible cathode material. 52 , 53 Li2FeP2S 6 as a cathode with oxysulfide glass electrolyte (Li3PO4 -Li2S-SiS2) was previously reported by Takada et. al. suggesting the possibility of utilizing thiophosphate frameworks for Li-ion battery. 25 However, the reversibility, long cyclability and charge compensation mechanisms of this class of materials are yet to be understood thoroughly. To the best of our knowledge this is the first time reporting the electrochemical performance of Li2FeP2S 6 as a cathode in Li-ion battery using liquid electrolyte. The first charging curve in the charge discharge cycle shows a long flat plateau around 2.9 V until 3.2 V attributed to 1.1 Li+ removal from the structure (theoretical capacity for 1 Li+ extraction is 82.7 mAh/g) (Figure 13c). Such high voltage Fe2+/3+ redox couple in sulfide system is achieved through the inductive effect caused by the P2S64– polyanion moiety that pushes the Fe2+/3+ redox couple to higher voltage than Fe containing pure sulfide system. 53 It is also important to note that when octahedrally coordinated Fe2+ d-band partially overlap with the ligand, S2–, p-band in the valence band, 25 , 52 it is well known that the charge compensation is achieved from both cation and anion oxidation that results in the deintercalation of more than 1 Li+ from the structure. 52 We do not have electronic band structure of Li2MP2S6 series of compounds; however, taking cue from the electronic band structure of vdW 2D compounds, M 2P2S6, the anionic redox cannot be completely ruled out as the eg d-band and S p-band have considerable contribution at the top of valence band leading to strong covalent Fe – S interaction. 37 , 38 However, only 0.6 moles of Li+ can be reinserted at the first discharge (1.8 V) indicating only part of the oxidized species are reversibly reduced. Such irreversibility can occur due to excessive oxidation of S2– ligand that causes instability to the structural framework. On the consecutive cycles, the structure is able to sustain a reversible (de)intercalation of 0.5 moles of Li +. Furthermore, on increasing the current density, the capacity continues to fade and could not recover the initial capacities when cycled back to the low current rates (Figure S17a). To evaluate the performance degradation, the batteries were broken at fully charged and discharged states after the first cycle, respectively, and washed with acetonitrile (ACN) before performing ex situ PXRD. To our surprise, both fully charged and discharged samples are completely transformed into the solvated phase similar to the H2O and NH3 intercalation scenarios (Figure S17b). However, it is also worth noticing that the peaks of the pristine compound are still intact, which means part of the cathode has intercalated solvent molecules and, in this case, it can either be ACN (during electrode washing) or could be from electrolyte solvent (EC/DMC-solvated Li+) during electrochemical charge-discharge. To evaluate these hypotheses, we soaked two pristine cathode films into the Li-ion electrolyte and ACN, respectively, for one day inside the glovebox and PXRD was collected (Figure S17c). The lines in the PXRD pattern of electrolyte-soaked cathode are broadened at the lower angle with reduced observed intensities for the remaining peaks with no clear lattice expansion. On the other hand, ACN soaked sample was transformed into solvated phase with a low angle peak at Q = 7 Å–1. Since both reactions were performed inside the glove box (O2 < 0.1 ppm and H2O < 0.1 ppm), we do not expect such a change in powder pattern due to hydration. So, we attribute such a change in PXRD to solvent intercalation into the layers of compound 2, still more detailed studies have to be carried out to verify the possibilities of such solvent molecule intercalations. Also, note that Takada et al reported the first Li-ion battery using Li2FeP2 S6 as cathode where they have shown one cycle of charge-discharge with similar capacity without any mention on the fate of the cathode. 25 We are currently working on understanding the origin of capacity fading and prospect of carbonate and polymer molecules intercalation into the structure. Recently, during our preparation of the manuscript we came across a work where solid-state Li-ion battery has been fabricated using Li2FeP2S6 as a cathode, but the achievable capacity is very similar to this work. 54

A series of non-vdW layered solids, Li2MP2S6 (M = V, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn) has been successfully synthesized through stoichiometric combination of metal powder, Li2S and P2S5, and metathesis routes (for V, Mn, Fe, Ni, and Zn). The crystal structure solution of the anhydrous phases through single crystal and synchrotron X-ray diffraction studies reveals a 2D layers of [Li/MP2S6]– interleaved by Li ions. PXRD, thermodiffractogram, and TG-DSC on the compounds show propensity for reversibly intercalate water leading to two distinct hydrated phases. The compounds also display affinity towards NH3 intercalation over water in their interlayer space. The magnetic measurements on Li2MP2S6 (M he AC impedance measurements of anhydrous Li2.56Zn0.72P2 S6 display significantly improved ionic conductivity compared to Li4 P2S6. Electrochemical testing on Li2FeP2 S6 reveal topotactic oxidative deintercalation and reductive insertion of Li+ during charge-discharge cycles. This new class of thiophosphate materials with interesting intercalation property can find application as adsorbent, electrode materials and solid electrolyte besides being excellent candidates for fundamental studies in low dimensions through exfoliated layers.
